docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 that family-owned corporations cannot be required under the Affordable Care Act to pay for insurance coverage for contraception.

headline.seo: Justices Rule in Favor of Hobby Lobby
headline.main: Supreme Court Rejects Contraceptives Mandate for Some Corporations
headline.sub: Health Law Violates Corporate Religious Liberty, Justices Say

docs.abstract: Supreme Court rules 5-to-4 that family-owned corporations cannot be required under Affordable Care Act to pay for insurance coverage for contraception, as it violates federal law protecting religious freedom; decision, in case that was brought by Hobby Lobby Stores and Conestoga Wood Specialties Corp, firms owned by Christian families, opens door to many challenges from corporations over laws that they claim violate their religious liberty.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 that family-owned corporations cannot be required under the Affordable Care Act to pay for insurance coverage for contraception.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Robert Pear and Michael D. Shear contributed reporting.

docs.lead_paragraph: A look at the parties, the lawyers and the issues in the Hobby Lobby case.

headline.main: Questions and Answers on the Contraceptives Case
